# Ways to find papers

- Searching as you need info

  - Non-comprehensive/casual searches in databases, google scholar, or catalog
  
  - Systematic searches

- Asking colleagues/advisor

- Keeping up with very new literature
  
  - Table of contents
  
  - Citation alerts
  
  - Popular science outlets / press releases

## "Related papers" features

:::: {.columns style='display: flex !important; height: 90%;'}

::: {.column width=40% style='display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center;'}


![](related_papers.jpg){fig-alt="Five cats on and near a patio, eating.  They represent similar papers.  Cats are papers, I guess." width=80%}

:::

::: {.column width=60% style='display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center;'}

- Varies by database and website

  - PubMed
  
    - Similar articles
    
    - Medical Subject Headings (MeSH)
  
  - Web of Science
  
    - Categories
    
    - Citation Topics Meso/Micro
    
  - ProQuest Natural Sciences
  
    - Suggested sources
    
    - Indexing terms

- Check in sidebars or bottom of page

- Look for labels: thesaurus, indexing, controlled vocabulary, subject header


:::

::::

  - General purpose, non-constrained AI invents plausible-sounding papers
  
  - Think about what you mean by AI - text searching?  synthesis?

  - Data ethics

:::

::: {.column width=50% style='display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center;'}

- Author names for databases

- Author names to get to research group pages

- Controlled vocabulary for databases

## Have you talked to your librarian?

:::: {.columns style='display: flex !important; height: 90%;'}

::: {.column width=50% style='justify-content: center; align-items: center;'}

![](keyboard_cat.JPG){fig-alt="A gray tabby cat wearing a white collar with red and black striped tie sits in front of a black keyboard on the floor." width=80%}

:::

::: {.column width=50% style='display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center;'}

- You've covered most or all of the relevant databases

  - [guides.ou.edu](https://guides.ou.edu)
  
- Your search comprehensiveness matches the scope of what you need to find

  - Some facts or methods
  
  - A narrative review (most common for dissertation/thesis)
  
  - A formal systematic review 


:::

::::



## Peer review

:::: {.columns style='display: flex !important; height: 90%;'}

::: {.column width=40% style='display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center;'}

![](peer_review.JPG){fig-alt="A very elderly black cat with yellow eyes and chewed-up ears looks at the camera, perhaps judgementally.  He represents peers reviewing your work." fig-align="center"}

:::

::: {.column width=60% style='display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center;'}

- Informal

  - Ask your advisor
  
  - Ask your senior lab members
  
  - Be cautious of time constraints

- Formal

  - Reviewers will let you know if you've missed something...

:::
